metadata.title: Product requirements

content:
Document statusDRAFTDocument owner
## Objective

A new design for approaching the outlier problem, incorporating some of the issues discussed in the NOOB seminar.

## Success metrics

| Goal | Metric |
| --- | --- |
| Learn to distinguish between trivial time series outliers and scope specific outliers | Given previously marked outliers on multiple levels of product sales what percentage of them does the system detect combined with how many points are detected as outliers that aren't marked as such |

## Requirements

| # | Requirement | Importance | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | A considerable dataset of marked outliers on all levels of product sales |  |  |
| 2 | A general approach as to how the thresholds will be set |  |  |

## Design

##

## Implementation

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
| A general approach as to how the thresholds will be set |  |  |

## Design

##

## Implementation

The design begins with an initial query of seasonality, special days and promo based on how a given sale for a week is out of bounds for some user defined range(More queries can be added) to differentiate whether the sales activity of a given week is explainable with some level of simplicity. I think just one of the queries leading to the next phase should be enough for the week to be passed on to the next phase of the system.

The seasonality threshold and special/promo days will be passed as parameters by the user, additionally a default value can be calculated from the set of highly seasonal products in the dataset. So the user can decide which time periods to query.

If both queries return false then we move on to the outlier detection phase. Before we move on however we should pause to think about Question #1 below.

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
outlier detection phase. Before we move on however we should pause to think about Question #1 below.

Prior to beginning this phase the system checks 2 more parameters. First at what scope do we want this system to run. Second which outlier algorithms to use.

I came up with two ways to handle the first parameter:

- Given a level say Reference stores the system would by default also use all higher levels

- The user can specify which levels they want particularly

The handling of the second parameter for the outlier algorithms is trivial, a simple selection array for desired algorithms should do the trick

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
e outlier algorithms is trivial, a simple selection array for desired algorithms should do the trick

After the desired levels and algorithms are chosen, the data is passed to the next phase . First the data from all levels are compared with the data from the same time last year(Question #2) and the forecast for the current week. For each level-forecast and level-last year comparison the system will output a 1/0 encoding based on whether or not  the difference in sales exceeds some threshold.Second if higher levels than just store are included checks what percentage of stores in the given scope showed the same activity(peaked/stable/dropped) during the given week.  Third the data from each level is passed to the user specified outlier detection algorithms(naive/hampel/PST...) which again output a series of 1/0 encodings based on whether or not the given week is an outlier based on a purely time series perspective. All these encodings take place in parallel.

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
is an outlier based on a purely time series perspective. All these encodings take place in parallel.

Additionally if the reference stores are included as a level, a comparison with the synthetic store is made in the same manner as last year and forecast comparisons.

Finally all these encoded 1/0's are multiplied with weights and summed up. If the result is greater than some final threshold. The week is marked as an outlier and passed on to some replacement algorithm.

After we feed the system the marked outlier data, it should be able to learn the weights(Maybe using a gradient descent optimization) as to how important each marking is forecast comparison,outlier algorithms etc.

## Open Questions

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
) as to how important each marking is forecast comparison,outlier algorithms etc.

## Open Questions

| Question | Answer | Date Answered |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1)Should we be passing all of the weeks/days that the product has been selling on any given scope, or should we be passing a single week/day within a limited window? |  |  |
| 2)Should we only be comparing Current year-week data with last year-week data. Could we be searching for monthly/weekly patterns. If so how should we specify this parameter? |  |  |
| 3)I did not yet think of a way to integrate store shares in the system, two ideas are that either they can be used as either a multiplicative coefficientor an initial query. So as to say the system would disregard a week from a certain store if the store share is under some threshold. |  |  |

metadata.title: Outlier Design Approach

content:
Document statusDRAFTDocument owner
## Introduction

The purpose of finding reference stores/products is so that we can use these references as base cases for out algorithms such as outlier detection, forecasting, etc. For example, if we have a sales spike for one week at a certain store, even though this might look like an outlier,. However, it may be the case that all reference stores of that store have jumps during that week. So this behavior is probably explainable and is not an outlier.

## Success metrics

| Goal | Metric |
| --- | --- |
| Create a synthetic Store/Product from Store/Product reference groups | MAPE w.r.t the original store's weekly sales |

## Objectives

For a given store or product find the best n stores/products that represent it (that have similar sales patterns ). So that when the sales of the reference stores/products are multiplied by certain weights the result is similar to our initial store’s/product’s sales.

## Input Parameters

metadata.title: Finding Reference Stores/Products and Creating Synthetic Stores/Products

content:
y certain weights the result is similar to our initial store’s/product’s sales.

## Input Parameters

| Parameter Name | Type | Explanation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| reference_group_type | string | Whether the data is going to be split based on store or product |
| hierarchy_split_level | int | The hierarchy level that the clustering algorithm will run on |
| ref_group_size | int | Size of reference groups |
| revenue_quantity | string | Whether to aggregate revenue or quantity |
| learning_rate | float | learning rate for stochastic gradient descent which is used to find reference group weights |
| num_rounds | int | number of rounds for stochastic gradient descent |

## Data Preparation

Given the input dataframe we aggregate the data into 52 weeks of sales or revenue. After that we split the data based on reference_group_type and hierarchy_split_level. The data is now ready to be passed on to the clustering algorithm.

## Overview

## Clustering

metadata.title: Finding Reference Stores/Products and Creating Synthetic Stores/Products

content:
evel. The data is now ready to be passed on to the clustering algorithm.

## Overview

## Clustering

The data that has been split w.r.t the given parameters is now clustered within these groups using Self Organizing Maps and LassoCV. After this is done we find the N(ref_group_size) reference stores within these clusters for each store.

## Synthetic Store/Product Creation and Selection

Now that we have a reference group given each store we want to represent this store as a linear combination of the stores in the reference group. For this we pass the 52 week sales of the reference store and the original store to a Stochastic Gradient Descent algorithm that optimizes the weights of each reference store. Then we choose the reference group and synthetic store with the lowest MAPE.

metadata.title: Finding Reference Stores/Products and Creating Synthetic Stores/Products

content:
## Objective

To provide new methods of diversifying our forecasting pool, and to be able to derive more complex forecasts from simpler ones

## Workflow

## Long Format Data Frame

| date | store_id | product_id | model_id | forecast_horizon | prediction |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |

## Hybrid Forecasting

Hybrid forecasting takes a long format data frame with forecasts for each granular level instance (e.g. date-store-product),

with the actual sales being included as a model. Given a user provided group by level, the algorithm assigns weights to each forecast

to derive a new forecast within each unique group. Finally an "ensemble_forecast" is returned in the long format. In the general case

this new forecast will be appended to the end of the initial long format data frame and used in the smart selection.

| Properties | Explanation |
| --- | --- |
| fill_method | how to fill missing forecasts |
| method | which weight optimizer to choose |

## Smart Selection

metadata.title: Hybrid Forecasting and Smart Selection

content:
| how to fill missing forecasts |
| method | which weight optimizer to choose |

## Smart Selection

Smart selection is basically hybrid forecasting with the weights being distributed such that one of the forecasts gets a weight of one

and the rest get zero. The difference is that after grouping the data frame based on the group by columns smart selection chooses the forecast for

each group via a custom error metric. For now this metric is distributing weights between WMAPE and Bias but it can be extended.

Once it selects the forecast for each unique group it merges them into a new forecast with model_id "smart_selection".

metadata.title: Hybrid Forecasting and Smart Selection
